definitions: grant a license or official permission to someone for a specific activity
formally authorize someone to carry out a particular activity or profession
examples: The state licenses all medical practitioners annually
The city will licence new taxi drivers next month
The board licensed her to practice law yesterday
The government licenses companies to broadcast on radio

definitions: grant a license or official permission to someone for a specific activity
formally authorize someone to carry out a particular activity or profession
examples: The state licenses all medical practitioners annually
The city will license new taxi drivers next month
The board licensed her to practice law yesterday
The government licenses companies to broadcast on radio

definitions: pass the tongue over something to taste, moisten, or clean it
defeat someone or something decisively in a competition or conflict
move quickly and lightly like a flame or tongue touching something
examples: The cat licked its paws after eating dinner
The child licked the ice cream cone eagerly
Our team completely licked them in the championship game
She finally licked her addiction after years of struggle
The flames licked at the wooden beams dangerously
The waves licked the shore in a gentle rhythm

definitions: be in or move into a horizontal position on a surface
be situated in a particular place or position geographically
say something untrue deliberately to deceive or mislead someone
remain in a specified state or condition without change
examples: She lies on the couch every afternoon to rest
The dog was lying in the sun all morning
The town lies twenty miles north of the capital
The valley lies between two mountain ranges
He lied about his whereabouts to his parents yesterday
She never lies even when the truth hurts
The responsibility lies with the management team entirely
The future lies in renewable energy sources

definitions: raise or move something to a higher position or level physically
remove or end a restriction, ban, or legal prohibition officially
steal something, especially by shoplifting or picking pockets informally
improve someone's mood or morale by encouragement or positive action
examples: She lifted the heavy box onto the shelf carefully
The crane lifted the steel beams into place yesterday
The government lifted the trade embargo after negotiations concluded
The court lifted the restraining order this morning
Someone lifted my wallet on the crowded subway train
The thief lifted several items from the store
The good news really lifted everyone's spirits yesterday
Her kind words lifted my mood considerably today

definitions: provide light to a space or make something visible with illumination
set fire to something or cause it to start burning
come to rest or land gently after flying or falling
examples: The candles light the room with a warm glow
Street lamps light the path for pedestrians at night
She lit the campfire with matches and dry kindling
He lights his cigarette despite the no smoking sign
The butterfly lighted on the flower petal gracefully
The bird lighted on the branch for a moment

definitions: reduce the weight or load of something to make it easier to carry
make something brighter in color or increase the amount of light
make or become more cheerful and less serious or worried
examples: We need to lighten the load before crossing the bridge
She lightened her backpack by removing unnecessary items
The sun began to lighten the eastern sky slowly
She decided to lighten her hair for the summer
His jokes always lighten the mood during meetings
The atmosphere lightened when she entered the room

definitions: transport goods on a flat-bottomed barge in shallow water
make something less heavy or reduce its weight
examples: They lighter goods from ship to shore daily
The company lighters cargo across the shallow harbor
We need to lighter the load before departure
They lightered the vessel to pass through shallows

definitions: warm up and stretch muscles in preparation for physical activity
attach a gun to its limber or wheeled ammunition carrier
examples: Athletes limber up before the race begins properly
The dancers limbered for thirty minutes before performing
The soldiers limbered the cannon for rapid deployment
They quickly limbered the artillery piece to move

definitions: restrict something to a particular amount, number, or extent
set or serve as a boundary or restriction for something
examples: The school limits class sizes to twenty students maximum
Please limit your presentation to ten minutes only
The river limits our expansion to the east
Budget constraints limit what we can accomplish this year

definitions: walk with difficulty because of an injured leg or foot
proceed slowly or with difficulty in a weak manner
examples: He limped off the field after injuring his ankle
The dog limped home with a thorn in its paw
The damaged ship limped into port for repairs
The company limped along despite financial difficulties

definitions: arrange people or things in a straight row or queue
cover the inner surface of something with a layer of material
mark or cover something with lines or linear patterns
examples: Students lined up outside the cafeteria for lunch
Trees line both sides of the avenue beautifully
She lined the drawer with decorative paper yesterday
They lined the coat with warm fleece material
The artist lined the canvas with bold strokes
Age had lined his face over the years

definitions: stay in a place longer than necessary because of reluctance to leave
continue to exist or persist although gradually becoming weaker
examples: She lingered at the party after everyone else left
He lingered over coffee to avoid going home
The smell of smoke lingered in the room
Doubts lingered in her mind about the decision

definitions: connect or join two or more things together physically or electronically
establish or suggest a connection or relationship between things or people
examples: The bridge links the island to the mainland
Click here to link to our website homepage
Scientists link smoking to various health problems conclusively
The evidence links him to the crime scene

definitions: apply lipstick cosmetic color to the lips for decoration
examples: She lipsticked her lips before the important meeting
The actress carefully lipsticked before going on stage

definitions: close a business and sell its assets to pay debts and obligations
eliminate or kill someone or something systematically and deliberately
convert assets or property into cash by selling them quickly
examples: The company was forced to liquidate after bankruptcy filing
They liquidated the subsidiary to cut their losses
The regime liquidated political opponents during the purge
The gang liquidated witnesses to prevent them from testifying
He liquidated his stock portfolio before the market crashed
They need to liquidate assets to raise capital quickly

definitions: speak with a speech defect where 's' sounds like 'th'
examples: The child lisped when saying words with 's' sounds
She lisped slightly when nervous during public speaking

definitions: write or include items in a list or catalog systematically
lean or cause a ship to lean to one side
enlist or enroll formally in military service historically
examples: Please list all ingredients on the recipe card
The website lists available properties for sale daily
The damaged ship listed badly to starboard side
The boat began to list after taking on water
Young men listed for military service during wartime
He listed with the navy at eighteen years old

definitions: give attention to sound or someone speaking using one's ears
take notice of and act on what someone says as advice
examples: She listens to music while studying every evening
Please listen carefully to the safety instructions now
Children should listen to their parents' guidance always
He never listens when I give him advice

definitions: scatter trash or objects untidily over an area or place
give birth to multiple offspring at once as animals do
examples: Don't litter the park with your trash please
Papers littered the floor after the windstorm yesterday
The cat littered five kittens in the garage
Our dog littered last night with seven puppies

definitions: remain alive and have life as a living organism
have one's home in a particular place or with someone
spend one's life in a particular way or under conditions
broadcast or perform in real time without recording or delay
examples: Humans cannot live without oxygen for very long
These plants live in harsh desert conditions successfully
She lives in Paris with her family now
They lived together for ten years before marrying
He lives dangerously as a stunt performer daily
She lived through the war as a child
The show will broadcast live from New York tonight
The band lives their performances with incredible energy

definitions: put a large amount of something onto or into a vehicle or container
burden someone or something heavily with weight, responsibility, or problems
put ammunition into a weapon or film into a camera
transfer data or a program into computer memory or onto a device
examples: Workers loaded the truck with furniture this morning
She loaded groceries into her car after shopping
Don't load him with too much responsibility immediately
The project loaded the team with unexpected challenges
He loaded his rifle before going hunting yesterday
She loaded film into the vintage camera carefully
The program takes forever to load on my computer
Please load the file onto the USB drive

definitions: spend time in a lazy, idle way without working or being productive
examples: He loafed around the house all weekend long
Stop loafing and start working on your homework

definitions: lend money or something valuable to someone for temporary use
examples: The bank loaned them money for their new house
Can you loan me your car for the weekend?

definitions: throw or hit something in a high arc through the air
hit a ball in a high arc over an opponent in sports
examples: He lobbed the ball over the fence easily
She lobbed grenades into the enemy position yesterday
The tennis player lobbed the ball over her opponent
He lobbed the goalkeeper from forty yards away

definitions: seek to influence politicians or public officials on a particular issue
gather or wait in a lobby or entrance hall of a building
examples: Environmental groups lobby Congress for stricter pollution laws
The company lobbied hard against the new regulations
Reporters lobbied outside the courtroom all morning long
Guests lobbied in the hotel entrance during registration

definitions: restrict something to a particular area or limit its spread
adapt something to meet the needs of a particular place or market
identify or determine the position or source of something precisely
examples: Doctors worked to localize the infection before it spread
They localized the fire damage to one room only
Companies localize products for different international markets effectively
We need to localize the software for Japanese users
Scientists localized the earthquake's epicenter within minutes accurately
The scan helps localize tumors in the body

definitions: discover the exact place or position of someone or something
establish something in a particular place or position officially
be situated in a particular place or position geographically
examples: Police located the missing child within hours yesterday
Can you locate the error in this code?
The company will locate its headquarters in Seattle
They decided to locate the factory near transportation
The restaurant locates conveniently near the train station
The village locates in a valley between mountains

definitions: fasten or secure something with a lock to prevent access
become fixed in position unable to move or function
hold someone in a tight embrace or wrestling hold
examples: Please lock the door when you leave tonight
She locked her valuables in the hotel safe
The wheels locked when he slammed the brakes suddenly
The computer screen locked and wouldn't respond anymore
The wrestlers locked in a fierce struggle yesterday
The lovers locked in a passionate embrace

definitions: provide temporary accommodation or shelter for someone to stay
become firmly fixed or stuck in a particular position accidentally
submit a formal complaint, appeal, or claim to authorities
examples: The hotel lodges fifty guests during peak season
They lodged with friends while visiting the city
A bone lodged in his throat during dinner
The bullet lodged in the wall behind him
She lodged a complaint with the manager yesterday
They lodged an appeal against the court decision

definitions: hit or kick a ball high up into the air deliberately
store something in a loft or attic space of a building
examples: The golfer lofted the ball over the water hazard
He lofted the soccer ball toward the goal perfectly
They lofted old furniture in the attic for storage
We lofted the holiday decorations until next year

definitions: record events, observations, or information systematically in a logbook or system
cut down trees and prepare timber for commercial use
achieve or accumulate a particular amount of time or distance
examples: The captain logs all activities in the ship's journal
Please log your hours on the timesheet daily
They log timber in the northern forests every summer
The company logs sustainably certified wood only now
The pilot logged five hundred hours of flight time
She logged ten thousand steps on her fitness tracker

definitions: direct one's gaze in a particular direction to see something
have the appearance of being in a particular state or condition
search for or try to find someone or something deliberately
face or be oriented in a particular direction architecturally
examples: Look at the beautiful sunset over the ocean
She looked through the window at the rain
You look tired after working all night long
The situation looks worse than we initially thought
I'm looking for my keys everywhere this morning
They're looking for a new apartment downtown
The house looks south toward the mountains magnificently
The windows look out onto the garden below

definitions: appear as a vague, large, or threatening shape, often suddenly
weave cloth on a loom machine by interlacing threads
examples: Dark clouds loomed on the horizon before the storm
The deadline looms closer with each passing day
She looms beautiful tapestries on her grandmother's loom
Artisans loomed fine silk fabrics for wealthy customers

definitions: form into or follow a curved or circular path or shape
fly an aircraft in vertical circles as an aerobatic maneuver
examples: She looped the rope around the post twice
The river loops through the valley in curves
The pilot looped the plane three times spectacularly
Stunt pilots loop their aircraft at air shows

definitions: release or set free from bonds or restraint deliberately
shoot an arrow or projectile from a bow or weapon
examples: They loosed the dogs to chase the intruder
The captain loosed the moorings at dawn yesterday
The archer loosed three arrows at the target
Warriors loosed volleys of arrows at enemies

definitions: make something less tight, firm, or fixed in position
become more relaxed in manner, behavior, or restrictions
examples: Please loosen this jar lid for me now
He loosened his tie after the meeting ended
She loosened up after a few drinks tonight
The rules have loosened considerably over the years

definitions: steal goods from a place during war, riot, or disorder
examples: Rioters looted stores during the civil unrest yesterday
Soldiers looted the conquered city for three days

definitions: cut off branches and twigs from a tree or shrub
remove unnecessary or unwanted parts from something
examples: The gardener lopped branches from the overgrown tree
They lopped the hedge to keep it neat
The editor lopped several paragraphs from the article
They lopped millions from the budget this year

definitions: run or move with a long bounding stride, especially of animals
examples: The horse loped across the field gracefully yesterday
He loped along the trail at an easy pace

definitions: act in a superior, domineering, or arrogant way toward others
examples: He lords his wealth over his poor relatives constantly
Don't lord it over others just because you won

definitions: cease to have or retain something through carelessness or misfortune
fail to win a game, competition, or argument against someone
become unable to find something or someone temporarily or permanently
examples: She lost her job during the economic downturn
He lost his temper when they insulted him
Our team lost the championship game by one point
She rarely loses an argument with anyone
I lost my keys somewhere in the house
They lost their way in the dense forest

definitions: sit or lie in a relaxed, lazy way without purpose
stand or move about in a relaxed, idle manner
examples: She lounged on the sofa watching television all day
Students lounged in the cafeteria between classes yesterday
Teenagers lounged outside the mall on Saturday afternoon
He lounged against the wall looking bored completely

definitions: feel deep romantic or familial affection for someone emotionally
like or enjoy something very much with great enthusiasm
examples: She loves her children more than anything else
They have loved each other for twenty years
I love chocolate ice cream on hot days
He loves playing guitar in his free time

definitions: make the deep sound characteristic of cattle mooing
examples: The cows lowed in the pasture at dawn
Cattle lowed as they waited for feeding time

definitions: move something to a position that is less high than before
reduce the amount, level, or strength of something significantly
make one's voice quieter or less loud in volume
examples: Workers lowered the flag to half-mast this morning
She lowered the window shade against the sun
The store lowered prices for the holiday sale
The medication helps lower blood pressure effectively
Please lower your voice in the library now
He lowered his tone when speaking to children

definitions: apply lubricant to machinery or parts to reduce friction
examples: The mechanic lubed the car's engine parts thoroughly
Remember to lube the chain on your bicycle regularly

definitions: carry or drag something heavy with great effort or difficulty
examples: She lugged her suitcase up three flights of stairs
They lugged equipment across the muddy field yesterday

definitions: ride on a light toboggan in a supine position down an icy track
examples: Athletes luge at speeds over ninety miles per hour
She luged down the Olympic track yesterday morning

definitions: soothe someone to sleep or calm with gentle sounds or movements
cause someone to feel falsely secure or confident about danger
examples: The mother lulled her baby to sleep gently
Ocean waves lulled us into peaceful slumber
Don't be lulled into complacency by early success
The quiet period lulled them into false security
